answers.title: Ngix 403 Forbidden - Ubuntu

answers.body_markdown:
Incorrect file permissions are another cause of the "403 Forbidden" error. The standard setting of **755** for directories and **644** for files is recommended for use with NGINX. The NGINX user also needs to be the owner of the files.

**Identify the NGINX User**

To begin, you will need to determine what user NGINX is running as. To do this, use the command:

    ps -ef | grep nginx

Check the first column, for any of the NGINX worker processes:

In this example, the NGINX worker process is running as the user nginx.

**Set File Ownership**

Go to the directory above the website's document root. For example, if your website's document root is **/usr/share/nginx/example.com** go to **/usr/share/nginx** with the command:

    cd /usr/share/nginx

Change the ownership of all the files from this point down to the nginx user with the command:

    sudo chown -R nginx:nginx

**Set Permissions**

Set the permissions of each directory at this location to **755** with the command:

    sudo chmod 755 [directory name]

For example, to set the permissions of the **example.com** directory, the command is:

    sudo chmod 755 example.com

Then go to the web document root directory:

    cd example.com

Change the permissions of all the files in this directory with the command:

    sudo chmod 644 *

> https://www.ionos.com/community/server-cloud-infrastructure/nginx/solve-an-nginx-403-forbidden-error/

Although it's not documented in [Chart Best Practices][1] yet, this issue ([#5465][2]) addresses namespaces considerations:

> In general, templates should not define a namespace. This is because
> Helm installs objects into the namespace provided with the `--namespace`
> flag. By omitting this information, it also provides templates with
> some flexibility for post-render operations (like `helm template |
> kubectl create --namespace foo -f -`)

As quoted, your best option is to add the `--namespace` to your install/upgrade commands instead of defining it on your templates.

  [1]: https://helm.sh/docs/chart_best_practices/
  [2]: https://github.com/helm/helm/issues/5465#issuecomment-473942223

answers.title: How would you deal with a situation requiring input, wanting to see output, and also wanting to write to a file in bash?

answers.body_markdown:
You could do

```
tee test.in | ./prog | tee test.out
```

`tee` writes stdin into a file and in stdout. So it lets the data that goes through it unchanged, and saves it into a file. See `man tee`

The first `tee` will save the input passed to the program, and the second `tee` will save the output of the program.

So at the end of the execution (exit with `Ctrl+C`), you will have a `test.in` file with the input, and an `test.out` file with the output.
answers.title: How would you deal with a situation requiring input, wanting to see output, and also wanting to write to a file in bash?

answers.body_markdown:
Are you looking for here documents?

```bash
./prog <<\____HERE
input
output
input2
output2
____HERE
```

This redirects standard input to come from the next lines of the file containing the command (or from your keyboard if you copy/paste this at the prompt). You can still of course redirect standard output and standard error to files (or whatever) separately if you like.

This is pretty much identical to

```bash
printf '%s\n' input \
    output \
    input2 \
    output2 |
./prog
```

answers.body_markdown:
This script will concatenate files that pandas can read into a DataFrame, preserving the header. All your columns need to be in the same order for this to work.

```python
# cat_header.py
import sys
import pandas as pd

header = True
for file in sys.argv[2:]:
    pd.read_csv(file).to_csv(sys.argv[1], header=header, index=False, mode="a")
    header = False
```

It runs as:

```bash
python3 cat_header.py output.csv *.csv
```

---
For `.txt` files:

```python
# cat_files.py
import sys

with open(sys.argv[1], "w") as out_fh:
    for file in sys.argv[2:]:
        with open(file, "r") as in_fh:
            out_fh.write("".join(in_fh.readlines()))
```

It runs as:

```bash
python3 cat_files.py output.txt *.txt
```

You can use recursion to get the desired result in case of N-number of teams in groups:

    def playoff(g1, g2, results):
        if len(g1) > 1:
            results.extend([(g1[0], g2[1]), (g2[0], g1[1])])
            playoff(g1[2:], g2[2:], results)
        elif len(g1) == 1:

answers.body_markdown:
You're on the right track; what you tried should work for you. If you get an error indicating that Sublime can't load the syntax, the most likely cause is that you deleted too much or altered the file in some other subtle way. `sublime-syntax` files are YAML, and as such they're sensitive to things like indentation. 

Note also that doing anything in the Packages folder directly is a Bad Idea; modifying a `sublime-package` file works in the short term, but they're upgraded by removing them and replacing them. So unless you're the one that made the file in the first place, modifying the contents directly is a recipe for your change to be unceremoniously removed at some future point when you least expect it.

Making the following changes worked for me. This uses the [OverrideAudit][1] package to make the change (disclaimer: I am the package author). That will let you easily make the change in a safe way and also let you know if the underlying package ever gets upgraded. 

1. Install [OverrideAudit][1]
2. From the Command Palette, select `OverrideAudit: Create Override`
3. Select the `SQL` package, then the `SQL.sublime-syntax` file
4. Use the find panel to search for `comments:` to see the context that contains all of the match patterns that represent comments. This should be around line 128, depending on what version of Sublime you're using

```yaml
  comments:
    - match: "--"
      scope: punctuation.definition.comment.sql
      push:
        - meta_scope: comment.line.double-dash.sql
        - match: \n
          pop: true
    - match: "#"
      scope: punctuation.definition.comment.sql
      push:
        - meta_scope: comment.line.number-sign.sql
        - match: \n
          pop: true
    - match: /\*
      scope: punctuation.definition.comment.sql
      push:
        - meta_scope: comment.block.c
        - match: \*/
          pop: true
```

5. Delete **just** the match rule that matches the comment style you don't want; make sure that you don't modify any other lines before or after or change the indent. The result should look like this when you're done:

```yaml
  comments:
    - match: "--"
      scope: punctuation.definition.comment.sql
      push:
        - meta_scope: comment.line.double-dash.sql
        - match: \n
          pop: true
    - match: /\*
      scope: punctuation.definition.comment.sql
      push:
        - meta_scope: comment.block.c
        - match: \*/
          pop: true
```

6. Save the syntax file. 

As soon as you save the file, the change should take effect immediately. If you check the Sublime console with `View > Show Console` you should see a line that says `generating syntax summary`, which indicates that Sublime has seen and reloaded the syntax. If there's an error during this process, it will be displayed here.

After performing these steps, your sample text renders like this (using the `Adaptive` theme and the `Monokai` color scheme:

[![Sample Image][2]][2]

If you've previously modified the actual `sublime-package` file this may not work. In such a case you may need to do a reinstall of Sublime to get the original file back; doing so won't remove your settings. Alternatively you can download the Windows portable version from the Sublime website (even if you're not using windows) and get the pristine package from there to replace the one you modified.


  [1]: https://packagecontrol.io/packages/OverrideAudit
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/rDU8d.png

answers.title: Termination character in char array

answers.body_markdown:
Your first string array is not null terminated.

     char hello[6] = {'h', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o', '\n'};

When passing a string which is not null terminated to printf (and other string related functions like strlen,strdup,strcat etc.), the behavior is undefined.
It may prints more bytes after your array, until it reaches a null (zero) byte (like at your case, shown as garbage), or it can crash the program.

To fix the behavior, you need all your string arrays end with null, i.e. have '\0' character at the end.

If you initialize a string like this

     char end[] = "end";

It is automatically null terminated and allocated the correct length to the char array declared.

answers.body_markdown:
The key to making things dynamic is to use measures instead of calculated columns or calculated tables (unless these are calculated within your measure).

---

I'd suggest creating a separate table to use as your x-axis.

    X-axis = GENERATESERIES ( 1, COUNTROWS ( 'All Interactions' ) )

(This is bigger than you need, but should work for the purpose.)

Put `'X-axis'[Value]` on your chart Axis and then define a measure to use for the Value field.

```
Contact Distribution = 
VAR Interactions = SELECTEDVALUE ( 'X-axis'[Value] )
VAR Summary =
    GROUPBY (
        'All interactions',
        'All interactions'[user_name],
        "total_interactions", COUNTX ( CURRENTGROUP (), 'All interactions'[user_name] )
    )
RETURN
    COUNTROWS ( FILTER ( Summary, [total_interactions] = Interactions ) )
```

This reads the value on the x-axis and then counts the number of users that have that many interactions in your `GROUPBY` summary table.

This dynamic now since the summary table is calculated inside a measure and can be responsive to filtering, unlike a fixed calculated table.
answers.title: Dynamic GROUPBY in DAX, PowerBI

items.body_markdown:
I am trying to create a file with fixed column lengths in Unix. The file contains Russian Cyrillic characters and those characters are interpreted different from the normal 1-byte characters.

I am using below script to modify the file (the delimiter of the columns is @-@ and the row delimiter is \r\n):

```
input_file=$1
output_file=$2

awk -F '@-@' '{printf("%-200s%-200s%-200s%-200s%-200s%-200s%-200s%-200s\r\n", $1, $2, $3, $4, $5, $6, $7, $8)}' $input_file > $output_file
```
For the columns with normal characters, the output file contains correctly 200 characters columns, but for a column with 30 Cyrillic characters, the output column contains only 170 characters. This way, the lines in the file won't have the same length because the Cyrillic characters occupy 2 bytes and the code will interpret the bytes and not the characters.

Example: НИКОЛАЕВНА has 10 characters, but the script calculates it as having 20 because it occupies 20 bytes.

One input file example:
```
НИКОЛАЕВНА@-@russ@-@12345@-@asklle@-@НИКОЛАЕВНА@-@454@-@111@-@asdfg
```
Can you please suggest a way to create the padding so that all the rows have the same number of characters?

Thank you!

answers.body_markdown:
If you send your receipt data to your server and validate purchases there, you don't need to handle `restore` state in iOS app. Just submit receipt data to the server and do validating there.

So in your code you can skip `restore` state handling and just call `self.sendTokenAndReceptForValidationFirstTime()` when you need it. However, I don't know whether your method checks for receipt existance. If receipt data is not present on device, you should first refresh receipt with `SKReceiptRefreshRequest`. And when you get receipt data then call `self.sendTokenAndReceptForValidationFirstTime()`.

Here is article about receipt validating from our blog: https://blog.apphud.com/receipt-validation/

And the same article in Russian if needed: https://habr.com/ru/company/apphud/blog/472188/

And this article from our blog also describes differences between refreshing a receipt and restoring transactions: https://blog.apphud.com/swift-tutorial-subscriptions/

answers.body_markdown:
I resolved it in a creative way.

The first issue were that k2 content can not be migrated to joomla for free if you want to move the content images too.
The first step was generate an RSS XML with all the posts and try to import them into my wordpress site.

To import them in wordpress I used [WP All Import][1]
This plugin moved the content from joomla to wordpress in some minutes INCLUDING THE IMAGES!
Nice!
But the images were linked to the joomla domain.

Our next step is retrieving each post image from joomla to wordpress and fix the links.

For this task I used [Auto Upload Images][2] 
Its process take about 10 minutes or more, but with amazing results.

The last step was to use the image of each post as excerpt.
Unfortunately I did not find plugins to do it, so it was a manual process.

Hope to be helpfull!


  [1]: https://wordpress.org/plugins/wp-all-import/
  [2]: https://wordpress.org/plugins/auto-upload-images/

answers.title: Skip RegEx grouping

answers.body_markdown:
Change the regex to 

    \([^()]*\)

which will match innermost parenthesed expressions only. If the strings your users supplies would contain parenthese pairs not containing expressions to substitute, you either have to be more strict about the pattern describing data to substitute or change the delimiting chars you use.

You might want to start with

    \([a-zA-Z_]+\)

as your pattern which matches parenthesed identifiers without digits.
answers.title: Skip RegEx grouping

        if self.initial_decay > 0:
            lr = lr * (1. / (1. + self.decay * K.cast(self.iterations,
                                                      K.dtype(self.decay))))
        # momentum
        shapes = [K.int_shape(p) for p in params]
        moments = [K.zeros(shape, name='moment_' + str(i)) for (i, shape) in enumerate(shapes)]
        self.weights = [self.iterations] + moments
        for p, g, m in zip(params, grads, moments):
            v = self.momentum * m - lr * g  # velocity
            self.updates.append(K.update(m, v))
    
            if self.nesterov:
                new_p = p + self.momentum * v - lr * g
            else:
                new_p = p + v
    
            # Apply constraints.
            if getattr(p, 'constraint', None) is not None:
                new_p = p.constraint(new_p)
    
            self.updates.append(K.update(p, new_p))
        return self.updates

which if I am not mistaken is being called at every iteration. (Because for various reasons I have trouble debugging the actual function I am guessing it's actual behavior). 

The line `moments = [K.zeros(shape, name='moment_' + str(i)) for (i, shape) in enumerate(shapes)]` creates an empty tensor to keep the moments as I get it. But when I calculate by hand I don't get the results I would expect from the theoretical formula.

For example for 2 iterations we have (assuming `self.momentum = 0.9` and not applying Nesterov for simplicity):

*Iter #1:*

`grads = self.get_gradients(loss, params)`: calculates the gradient, let's call them `grad1`.  
...  
Inside `for p, g, m in zip(params, grads, moments)` loop:  
`v1 = self.momentum * m - lr * g  = 0.9*0 - lr * grad1 = - lr * grad1`.  
Update `m`->`v1` and `p`->`new_p = p + v1 = - lr * grad1`.  

*Iter #2:*  

`grads = self.get_gradients(loss, params)`: calculates the gradient, let's call them `grad2`.  
...  
Inside `for p, g, m in zip(params, grads, moments)` loop:  
(`m` is initialized at every iteration to `0` I think. Correct me if I am wrong)  
`v2 = self.momentum * m - lr * g  = 0.9*0 - lr * grad2 = - lr * grad2`. 
Update `m`->`v and `p -> new_p = p + v = v1 + v2 = - lr * grad1 - lr * grad2`.  

I would expect something like: `- 0.9*lr * grad1 - lr * grad2` to come up here. Also, judging from my calculations `m` (moments) does not seem to be used so I am probably mistaken somehow in my calculations. Can someone explain the mentality behind SGD in keras?

Also, I have some trouble understanding what that `for` is iterating on which might have given me a clue what am I missing here.

  [1]: https://github.com/keras-team/keras/blob/master/keras/optimizers.py#L164
items.title: Explaining SGD in keras functionality

answers.body_markdown:
Although not explicitly mentioned in the API documentation of `executeBatch`, the behaviour is specified by the [JDBC 4.3 Specification][1] in section _14.1.2 Successful Execution_:

> The statement's batch is reset to empty once executeBatch returns.

Although this is specified in a section called 'Successful Execution', it is also the intended behaviour for unsuccessful execution.

In short, when you call `executeBatch()` the current batch of statements is submitted to the database server and cleared.


  [1]: https://jcp.org/aboutJava/communityprocess/mrel/jsr221/index3.html
answers.title: Does executeBatch() also clear the list of commands?

items.body_markdown:
The documentation of [`Statement.executeBatch()`][executeBatch] is not clear on this, but I assume that calling it will empty the `Statement` object's current list of SQL commands in the same way as [`clearBatch()`][clearBatch] does. I'm also assuming the same is true for [`PreparedStatement`][PreparedStatement].

I suppose it is possible to continue using the `Statement` after calling [`Statement.executeBatch()`][executeBatch], i.e. add another batch of commands and execute them.

[executeBatch]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/10/docs/api/java/sql/Statement.html#executeBatch()
[clearBatch]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/10/docs/api/java/sql/Statement.html#clearBatch()
[PreparedStatement]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/10/docs/api/java/sql/PreparedStatement.html

answers.body_markdown:
You can do conditional aggregation:

    SELECT
        h.hotel_id,
        h.hotel_name,
        COUNT(r.room_no) || ' total rooms ' 
            || SUM(CASE WHEN r.room_no > 2 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) 
            || ' have more than 2 bedrooms ' AS ACCOMODATION_AVAILABLE
    FROM hotel h
    INNER JOIN room r ON h.hotel_id = r.hotel_id
    GROUP BY h.hotel_id, h.hotel_name;

Note: table aliases make the queries shorter and easier to understand. I modified your query to use them.
answers.title: SQL: combining a total count along with a conditional count

    FROM hotel h JOIN
         room r
         ON h.hotel_id = r.hotel_id
    GROUP BY h.hotel_id, h.hotel_name;
